p: We define MR as a deliberate and strategic ‘move from climate-induced harm’ - this encompasses moving people and the resources they value such as homes, businesses, infrastructure, ecosystems, and other assets from areas of risk and resettling them in safer locations (Alexander et al., 2012, Bowman and Henquinet, 2015, Hino et al., 2017, Ajibade, 2019). For some people, retreat may mean creating new setbacks (Abel et al., 2011, Pilkey et al., 2016), revoking building permits (Nalau et al., 2015), re-zoning and land acquisition (Dyckman et al., 2014) or outright relocation from hazardous zones (Herrmann, 2017). MR is considered an alternative to sudden displacement (Johnson, 2012, Koslov, 2016, Scott et al., 2020) and typically involves government and/or community participation (Sipe and Vella, 2014, Ferris, 2015, Mortreux et al., 2018). For example, Taro, the capital of Choiseul Province in the Solomon Islands, is set to become the first capital globally to relocate residents and services due to the threat of SLR (Albert et al., 2016). Indonesia has also announced the relocation of its capital city Jakarta to another location due to rising seas and sinking land (Chappell, 2019). Other examples include the relocation of national treasures such as lighthouses in Denmark (The Guardian, 2019) and North Carolina (Allen, 2019).
